headline: Local Republicans, pundits react to Trump's endorsement of J. D. Vance
author: Ashley Kirklen
sentences: "I think even the endorsement itself, has less of that, you know, tone of this is the only acceptable candidate, and really just says that, you know, Vance came out ahead of several others who were also up for the endorsement," said University of Cincinnati political science professor David Niven.

Mike Gibbons said in a statement to WLWT:
"While I would have loved the endorsement, I continue to be in a strong position in this race..."
And Matt Dolan says the other four candidates: "...have instead embraced lies and undermined the Constitution to go all-in for one endorsement."

Josh Mandel tweeting:
“I look forward to earning his endorsement in the general election and working with him to defeat Tim Ryan in November.”
Timken also said in part: "...I look forward to having President Trump's endorsement in the General Election."
In the past, Trump's seal of approval has worked for candidates like Mike Carey in Ohio's 15th Congressional District, but has also been a flop like with Alabama U.S. Senate candidate Mo Brooks.

The least of those has been Vance, who at one point came under fire for calling himself a “never-Trump guy.”
But with Vance's changed tune, and unique story, Trump says it's all about winning.
If it goes poorly, he's going to take an awful lot of the blame and it's really going to take, you know, the shine off the Trump endorsement, magic," Niven said.
"I think there's nothing right now that unites the Republican Party more than Joe Biden's presidency, which we think is a failure," Triantafilou said.
Triantafilou knows Vance holds the Trump card among his other GOP candidates in this primary, but he says this is not a rift in the party as a whole.
"I have previously endorsed Jane Timken, but you know, like every good Republican, I'm going to support whoever the nominee is," Triantafilou said.

, Ohio —
In a field of Republican candidates for the Ohio U.S. Senate seat, the messages and stances sound like a page from the same notebook.
In a field of Republican candidates for the Ohio U.S. Senate seat, the messages and stances sound like a page from the same notebook.
"I mean, it's the most coveted endorsement right now and the Republican primary," said Hamilton County GOP Chair Alex Triantafilou.
All of the candidates have touted their support for former President Donald Trump on the campaign trail.
Triantafilou has backed Jane Timken in the past but says he's about party first.
The real test will be to see if Trump's endorsement is magic among Ohio voters.
"If this goes well, it's going to be a huge political feather for Trump.
Four of the major Republican candidates are reacting to the endorsement.
Now, one candidate, J. D. Vance, has been singled out among the class.

However, political pundits say it doesn't mean an automatic victory.
The latest polls show Vance third behind Mandel and Gibbons.
It's more of a differentiator.
